ADVERSE REACTIONS
Information on adverse reactions associated with the use of CYTOXAN (cyclophosphamide) is arranged according
to body system affected or type of reaction. The adverse reactions are listed in order of decreasing incidence.
The most serious adverse reactions are described in the WARNINGS section.
Reproductive System
See WARNINGS for information on impairment of fertility.
Digestive System
Nausea and vomiting commonly occur with cyclophosphamide therapy. Anorexia and, less frequently, abdom-
inal discomfort or pain and diarrhea may occur. There are isolated reports of hemorrhagic colitis, oral mucosal
ulceration and jaundice occurring during therapy. These adverse drug effects generally remit when cyclophos-
phamide treatment is stopped.
Skin and Its Structures
Alopecia occurs commonly in patients treated with cyclophosphamide. The hair can be expected to grow back
after treatment with the drug or even during continued drug treatment, though it may be different in texture or
color. Skin rash occurs occasionally in patients receiving the drug. Pigmentation of the skin and changes in
nails can occur. Very rare reports of Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis have been
received during postmarketing surveillance; due to the nature of spontaneous adverse event reporting, a definitive
causal relationship to cyclophosphamide has not been established. 
Hematopoietic System
Leukopenia occurs in patients treated with cyclophosphamide, is related to the dose of drug, and can be used
as a dosage guide. Leukopenia of less than 2000 cells/mm3 develops commonly in patients treated with an
initial loading dose of the drug, and less frequently in patients maintained on smaller doses. The degree of
neutropenia is particularly important because it correlates with a reduction in resistance to infections. Fever
without documented infection has been reported in neutropenic patients.
Thrombocytopenia or anemia develop occasionally in patients treated with CYTOXAN. These hematologic ef-
fects usually can be reversed by reducing the drug dose or by interrupting treatment. Recovery from leukope-
nia usually begins in 7 to 10 days after cessation of therapy.
Urinary System
See WARNINGS for information on cystitis and urinary bladder fibrosis.
Hemorrhagic ureteritis and renal tubular necrosis have been reported to occur in patients treated with cyclo-
phosphamide. Such lesions usually resolve following cessation of therapy.
Infections
See WARNINGS for information on reduced host resistance to infections.
Carcinogenesis
See WARNINGS for information on carcinogenesis.
Respiratory System
Interstitial pneumonitis has been reported as part of the postmarketing experience. Interstitial pulmonary fibrosis
has been reported in patients receiving high doses of cyclophosphamide over a prolonged period.
Other
Anaphylactic reactions have been reported; death has also been reported in association with this event. Possible
cross-sensitivity with other alkylating agents has been reported. SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion)
has been reported with the use of cyclophosphamide. Malaise and asthenia have been reported as part of the
postmarketing experience.
OVERDOSAGE
No specific antidote for cyclophosphamide is known. Overdosage should be managed with supportive
measures, including appropriate treatment for any concurrent infection, myelosuppression, or cardiac toxicity should
it occur.
DOSAGE AND ADMINISTRATION
Treatment of Malignant Diseases
Adults and Children
When used as the only oncolytic drug therapy, the initial course of CYTOXAN for patients with no hematologic
deficiency usually consists of 40 to 50 mg/kg given intravenously in divided doses over a period of 2 to 5 days.
Other intravenous regimens include 10 to 15 mg/kg given every 7 to 10 days or 3 to 5 mg/kg twice weekly.
Oral CYTOXAN dosing is usually in the range of 1 to 5 mg/kg/day for both initial and maintenance dosing.
Many other regimens of intravenous and oral CYTOXAN have been reported. Dosages must be adjusted in
accord with evidence of antitumor activity and/or leukopenia. The total leukocyte count is a good, objective
guide for regulating dosage. Transient decreases in the total white blood cell count to 2000 cells/mm3
(following short courses) or more persistent reduction to 3000 cells/mm3 (with continuing therapy) are tolerated
without serious risk of infection if there is no marked granulocytopenia.
When CYTOXAN is included in combined cytotoxic regimens, it may be necessary to reduce the dose of
CYTOXAN as well as that of the other drugs.
CYTOXAN and its metabolites are dialyzable although there are probably quantitative differences depending
upon the dialysis system being used. Patients with compromised renal function may show some measurable changes
in pharmacokinetic parameters of CYTOXAN metabolism, but there is no consistent evidence indicating a need
for CYTOXAN dosage modification in patients with renal function impairment.
Treatment of Nonmalignant Diseases
Biopsy Proven “Minimal Change” Nephrotic Syndrome In Children
An oral dose of 2.5 to 3 mg/kg daily for a period of 60 to 90 days is recommended. In males, the incidence of
oligospermia and azoospermia increases if the duration of CYTOXAN treatment exceeds 60 days. Treatment
beyond 90 days increases the probability of sterility. Adrenocorticosteroid therapy may be tapered and discon-
tinued during the course of CYTOXAN therapy. See PRECAUTIONS concerning hematologic monitoring.
Preparation and Handling of Solutions
Parenteral drug products should be inspected visually for particulate matter and discoloration prior to adminis-
tration, whenever solution and container permit.
Add the diluent to the vial and shake it vigorously to dissolve. If the powder fails to dissolve immediately and
completely, it is advisable to allow the vial to stand for a few minutes. Use the quantity of diluent shown below
to constitute the product:
For Direct Injection
CYTOXAN should be prepared for parenteral use by adding 0.9% sterile sodium chloride solution. Solutions of CYTOXAN
may be injected intravenously, intramuscularly, intraperitoneally, or intrapleurally if constituted by adding 0.9%
sterile sodium chloride solution.
For Infusion
CYTOXAN (cyclophosphamide) may be prepared for parenteral use by infusion using any of the following methods:
1. CYTOXAN constituted with 0.9% sterile sodium chloride may be infused without further dilution.
2. CYTOXAN constituted with 0.9% sterile sodium chloride may be infused following further dilution in the
following:
Dextrose Injection, USP (5% dextrose)
Dextrose and Sodium Chloride Injection, USP (5% dextrose and 0.9% sterile sodium chloride)
5% Dextrose and Ringer’s Injection
Lactated Ringer’s Injection, USP
Sodium Chloride Injection, USP (0.45% sterile sodium chloride)
Sodium Lactate Injection, USP (1/6 molar sodium lactate)
3. CYTOXAN sterile powder may be prepared for parenteral use by infusion by adding Sterile Water for Injection,
USP. CYTOXAN, constituted in water, is hypotonic and should not be injected directly. Prior to infusion,
solutions of CYTOXAN sterile powder constituted in Sterile Water for Injection, USP must be further diluted
in one of the following:
Dextrose Injection, USP (5% dextrose)
Dextrose and Sodium Chloride Injection, USP (5% dextrose and 0.9% sterile sodium chloride)
5% Dextrose and Ringer’s Injection
Lactated Ringer’s Injection, USP
Sodium Chloride Injection, USP (0.45% sterile sodium chloride)
Sodium Lactate Injection, USP (1/6 molar sodium lactate)
Stability of Constituted Parenteral Solutions
CYTOXAN (prepared for either direct injection or infusion) is chemically and physically stable for 24 hours at room
temperature or for six days in the refrigerator; it does not contain any antimicrobial preservative and thus care
must be taken to assure the sterility of prepared solutions.
The osmolarities of solutions of CYTOXAN constituted with water and 0.9% sterile sodium chloride solution
are found in the following table:
Isotonic 0.9% sterile sodium chloride solution has an osmolarity of 289 mOsm/L.
For Oral Administration
Extemporaneous liquid preparations of CYTOXAN for oral administration may be prepared by dissolving CYTOXAN
in Aromatic Elixir, N.F. Such preparations should be stored under refrigeration in glass containers and used
within 14 days.
HOW SUPPLIED
CYTOXAN® (cyclophosphamide for injection, USP) contains cyclophosphamide monohydrate and is supplied in
vials for single-dose use.
CYTOXAN (cyclophosphamide for injection, USP).

Store vials at or below 77° F (25° C). During transport or storage of CYTOXAN vials, temperature influences
can lead to melting of the active ingredient, cyclophosphamide. Vials containing melted substance can be
visually differentiated. Melted cyclophosphamide is a clear or yellowish viscous liquid usually found as a connected
phase or in droplets in the affected vials. Do not use CYTOXAN vials if there are signs of melting.
CYTOXAN® Tablets, 25 mg, and CYTOXAN Tablets, 50 mg, are white tablets with blue flecks containing
25 mg and 50 mg cyclophosphamide (anhydrous), respectively.
CYTOXAN Tablets (cyclophosphamide tablets, USP). 
NDC 0015-0503-01
50 mg, bottles of 100
NDC 0015-0504-01
25 mg, bottles of 100
Store tablets at or below 77°F (25°C); tablets will withstand brief exposure to temperatures up to 86°F (30°C),
but should be protected from temperatures above 86°F (30°C).
Procedures for proper handling and disposal of anticancer drugs should be considered. Several guidelines
on this subject have been published.1-8 There is no general agreement that all of the procedures recommended
in the guidelines are necessary or appropriate.
To minimize the risk of dermal exposure, always wear impervious gloves when handling vials containing
CYTOXAN sterile powder for injection, or bottles containing CYTOXAN tablets. This includes all handling
activities in clinical settings, pharmacies, storerooms, and home healthcare settings, including during unpacking
and inspection, transport within a facility, and dose preparation and administration.

Sub-sections.Title: RITUXIMAB UNITED STATES PRESCRIBING INFORMATION
Sub-sections.Content:
HIGHLIGHTS OF PRESCRIBING INFORMATION 
These highlights do not include all the information needed to use 
Rituxan safely and effectively.  See full prescribing information 
for Rituxan. 
 
Rituxan (rituximab)  
Injection for Intravenous Use 
Initial U.S. Approval:  1997 
WARNING:  FATAL INFUSION REACTIONS, TUMOR LYSIS 
SYNDROME (TLS), SEVERE MUCOCUTANEOUS REACTIONS, 
and PROGRESSIVE MULTIFOCAL LEUKOENCEPHALOPATHY 
(PML) 
See full prescribing information for complete boxed warning. 
• Fatal infusion reactions within 24 hours of Rituxan infusion occur; 
approximately 80% of fatal reactions occurred with first infusion.  
Monitor patients and discontinue Rituxan infusion for severe 
reactions (5.1). 
• Tumor lysis syndrome (5.2). 
• Severe mucocutaneous reactions, some with fatal outcomes (5.3). 
• PML resulting in death (5.4). 
 
--------------------------RECENT MAJOR CHANGES------------------------ 
Warnings and Precautions, PML (5.4) 
 
09/2008 
---------------------------INDICATIONS AND USAGE------------------------ 
Rituxan is a CD20-directed cytolytic antibody indicated for the treatment 
of the following: 
• Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma (NHL) (1.1) 
• Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) in combination with methotrexate in adult 
patients with moderately-to severely-active RA who have inadequate 
response to one or more TNF antagonist therapies (1.2) 
 ------------------------DOSAGE AND ADMINISTRATION------------------ 
DO NOT ADMINISTER AS AN IV PUSH OR BOLUS. 
• The dose for NHL is 375 mg/m2 (2.1). 
• The dose as a component of Zevalin (Ibritumomab tiuxetan) 
Therapeutic Regimen is 250 mg/m2 (2.2). 
• The dose for Rheumatoid Arthritis is two-1000 mg IV infusions 
separated by 2 weeks in combination with methotrexate.  
Methylprednisolone 100 mg IV or equivalent glucocorticoid is 
recommended 30 minutes prior to each infusion (2.3). 
---------------------DOSAGE FORMS AND STRENGTHS------------------ 
• 100 mg/10 mL and 500 mg/50 mL solution in a single-use vial (3). 
------------------------------CONTRAINDICATIONS-------------------------- 
None. 
-----------------------WARNINGS AND PRECAUTIONS-------------------- 
• Tumor lysis syndrome – administer prophylaxis and monitor renal 
function (5.2). 
• PML - monitor neurologic function.  Discontinue Rituxan (5.4). 
• Hepatitis B reactivation with fulminant hepatitis, sometimes fatal – 
screen high risk patients and monitor HBV carriers during and several 
months after therapy.  Discontinue Rituxan if reactivation occurs (5.5). 
• 
Cardiac arrhythmias and angina can occur and can be life threatening.  
Monitor patients with these conditions closely (5.7). 
• 
Bowel obstruction and perforation - evaluate complaints of abdominal 
pain (5.9). 
• 
Do not administer live virus vaccines prior to or during Rituxan (5.10). 
• 
Monitor CBC at regular intervals for severe cytopenias (5.11, 6.1). 
------------------------------ADVERSE REACTIONS--------------------------- 
• Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma (NHL) - Common adverse reactions 
( ≥ 25%) in clinical trials were:  infusion reactions, fever, lymphopenia, 
chills, infection and asthenia (6.1). 
• Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) - Common adverse reactions ( ≥ 5%):  
hypertension, nausea, upper respiratory tract infection, arthralgia, 
pruritus, and pyrexia (6.2).  Other important adverse reactions include 
infusion reactions, serious infections, and cardiovascular events (6.2). 
 
To report SUSPECTED ADVERSE REACTIONS, contact Genentech 
at 1-888-835-2555 or FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or 
www.fda.gov/medwatch. 
-------------------------------DRUG INTERACTIONS-------------------------- 
• Renal toxicity when used in combination with cisplatin (5.8). 
-----------------------USE IN SPECIFIC POPULATIONS-------------------- 
• Pregnancy:  Limited human data; B-cell lymphocytopenia occurred in 
infants exposed in utero (8.1). 
• Nursing Mothers: Caution should be exercised when administered to a 
nursing woman (8.3). 
 
See 17 for PATIENT COUNSELING INFORMATION and 
Medication Guide. 
Revised: 09/2008 
 
Page 96

FULL PRESCRIBING INFORMATION 
1 
WARNING:  FATAL INFUSION REACTIONS, TUMOR LYSIS 
2 
SYNDROME (TLS), SEVERE MUCOCUTANEOUS REACTIONS, 
3 
and  
4 
PROGRESSIVE MULTIFOCAL LEUKOENCEPHALOPATHY 
5 
(PML) 
6 
Infusion Reactions 
7 
Rituxan administration can result in serious, including fatal infusion 
8 
reactions.  Deaths within 24 hours of Rituxan infusion have occurred.  
9 
Approximately 80% of fatal infusion reactions occurred in association 
10 
with the first infusion.  Carefully monitor patients during infusions.  
11 
Discontinue Rituxan infusion and provide medical treatment for 
12 
Grade 3 or 4 infusion reactions [see Warnings and Precautions (5.1), 
13 
Adverse Reactions (6.1)]. 
14 
Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS) 
15 
Acute renal failure requiring dialysis with instances of fatal outcome 
16 
can occur in the setting of TLS following treatment of non-Hodgkin’s 
17 
lymphoma (NHL) patients with Rituxan [see Warnings and 
18 
Precautions (5.2), Adverse Reactions (6)]. 
19 
Severe Mucocutaneous Reactions 
20 
Severe, including fatal, mucocutaneous reactions can occur in patients 
21 
receiving Rituxan [see Warnings and Precautions (5.3), Adverse 
22 
Reactions (6)]. 
23 
Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) 
24 
JC virus infection resulting in PML and death can occur in patients 
25 
receiving Rituxan [see Warnings and Precautions (5.4), Adverse 
26 
Reactions (6.4)]. 
27 
 
28 
1 INDICATIONS AND USAGE 
29 
1.1 Non–Hodgkin’s Lymphoma (NHL) 
30 
 Rituxan (rituximab) is indicated for the treatment of patients with: 
31 
• Relapsed or refractory, low-grade or follicular, CD20-positive, B-cell 
32 
NHL as a single agent 
33 
• Previously untreated follicular, CD20-positive, B-cell NHL in 
34 
combination with CVP chemotherapy 
35 
• Non-progressing (including stable disease), low-grade, CD20-positive, 
36 
B-cell NHL, as a single agent, after first-line CVP chemotherapy 
37 
• Previously untreated diffuse large B-cell, CD20-positive NHL in 
38 
combination with CHOP or other anthracycline-based chemotherapy 
39 
regimens 
40 
Page 98
 
 
 
1.2 Rheumatoid Arthritis 
41 
 Rituxan (rituximab) in combination with methotrexate is indicated to 
42 
reduce signs and symptoms and to slow the progression of structural 
43 
damage in adult patients with moderately-to severely- active rheumatoid 
44 
arthritis who have had an inadequate response to one or more TNF 
45 
antagonist therapies. 
46 
2 DOSAGE AND ADMINISTRATION 
47 
2.1 Administration 
48 
 DO NOT ADMINISTER AS AN INTRAVENOUS PUSH OR BOLUS. 
49 
 Premedicate before each infusion [see Dosage and Administration 
50 
(2.5)].  Administer only as an intravenous infusion [see Dosage and 
51 
Administration (2.5)]. 
52 
• First Infusion:  Initiate infusion at a rate of 50 mg/hr. In the absence of 
53 
infusion toxicity, increase infusion rate by 50 mg/hr increments every 
54 
30 minutes, to a maximum of 400 mg/hr. 
55 
• Subsequent Infusions:  Initiate infusion at a rate of 100 mg/hr.  In the 
56 
absence of infusion toxicity, increase rate by 100 mg/hr increments at 
57 
30-minute intervals, to a maximum of 400 mg/hr. 
58 
• Interrupt the infusion or slow the infusion rate for infusion reactions 
59 
[see Boxed Warning, Warnings and Precautions (5.1)].  Continue the 
60 
infusion at one-half the previous rate upon improvement of symptoms. 
61 
2.2 Recommended Dose for Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma (NHL) 
62 
 The recommended dose is 375 mg/m2 as an intravenous infusion 
63 
according to the following schedules: 
64 
• Relapsed or Refractory, Low-Grade or Follicular, CD20-Positive, 
65 
B-Cell NHL 
66 
Administer once weekly for 4 or 8 doses. 
67 
• Retreatment for Relapsed or Refractory, Low-Grade or Follicular, 
68 
CD20-Positive, B-Cell NHL 
69 
Administer once weekly for 4 doses. 
70 
• Previously Untreated, Follicular, CD20-Positive, B-Cell NHL 
71 
Administer on Day 1 of each cycle of CVP chemotherapy, for up to 
72 
8 doses. 
73 
• Non-progressing, Low-Grade, CD20-Positive, B-cell NHL, after 
74 
first-line CVP chemotherapy 
75 
Following completion of 6−8 cycles of CVP chemotherapy, administer 
76 
once weekly for 4 doses at 6-month intervals to a maximum of 
77 
16 doses. 
78 
• Diffuse Large B-Cell NHL 
79 
Administer on Day 1 of each cycle of chemotherapy for up to 
80 
8 infusions. 
81 
2.3 Recommended Dose as a Component of Zevalin 
82 
• Infuse rituximab 250 mg/m2 within 4 hours prior to the administration 
83 
of Indium-111-(In-111-) Zevalin and within 4 hours prior to the 
84 
administration of Yttrium-90- (Y-90-) Zevalin. 
85 
Page 99
 
 
 
• Administer Rituxan and In-111-Zevalin 7-9 days prior to Rituxan and 
86 
Y-90- Zevalin. 
87 
• Refer to the Zevalin package insert for full prescribing information 
88 
regarding the Zevalin therapeutic regimen. 
89 
2.4 Recommended Dose for Rheumatoid Arthritis 
90 
• Two-1000 mg intravenous infusions separated by 2 weeks. 
91 
• Glucocorticoids administered as methylprednisolone 100 mg 
92 
intravenous or its equivalent 30 minutes prior to each infusion are 
93 
recommended to reduce the incidence and severity of infusion reactions.  
94 
Safety and efficacy of retreatment have not been established in 
95 
controlled trials [see Warnings and Precautions (5.14)]. 
96 
•  Rituxan is given in combination with methotrexate. 
97 
2.5 Recommended Concomitant Medications 
98 
 Premedicate before each infusion with acetaminophen and an 
99 
antihistamine. 
100 
2.6 Preparation for Administration 
101 
 Use appropriate aseptic technique.  Parenteral drug products should be 
102 
inspected visually for particulate matter and discoloration prior to 
103 
administration.  Do not use vial if particulates or discoloration is present.  
104 
Withdraw the necessary amount of Rituxan and dilute to a final 
105 
concentration of 1 to 4 mg/mL in an infusion bag containing either 0.9% 
106 
Sodium Chloride, USP, or 5% Dextrose in Water, USP.  Gently invert the 
107 
bag to mix the solution.  Do not mix or dilute with other drugs.  Discard 
108 
any unused portion left in the vial. 
109 
3 DOSAGE FORMS AND STRENGTHS 
110 
 100 mg/10 mL single-use vial 
111 
 500 mg/50 mL single-use vial 
112 
4 CONTRAINDICATIONS 
113 
 None. 
114 
5 WARNINGS AND PRECAUTIONS 
115 
5.1 Infusion Reactions 
116 
 Rituxan can cause severe, including fatal, infusion reactions.  Severe 
117 
reactions typically occurred during the first infusion with time to onset of 
118 
30−120 minutes.  Rituxan-induced infusion reactions and sequelae include 
119 
urticaria, hypotension, angioedema, hypoxia, bronchospasm, pulmonary 
120 
infiltrates, acute respiratory distress syndrome, myocardial infarction, 
121 
ventricular fibrillation, cardiogenic shock, or anaphylactoid events. 
122 
 Premedicate patients with an antihistamine and acetaminophen prior to 
123 
dosing.  Institute medical management (e.g. glucocorticoids, epinephrine, 
124 
bronchodilators, or oxygen) for infusion reactions as needed.  Depending 
125 
on the severity of the infusion reaction and the required interventions, 
126 
consider resumption of the infusion at a minimum 50% reduction in rate 
127 
after symptoms have resolved.  Closely monitor the following patients: 
128 
those with pre-existing cardiac or pulmonary conditions, those who 
129 
Page 100
 
 
 
experienced prior cardiopulmonary adverse reactions, and those with high 
130 
numbers of circulating malignant cells ( ≥ 25,000/mm3). [See Boxed 
131 
Warning, Warnings and Precautions (5.7), Adverse Reactions (6.1).] 
132 
5.2 Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS) 
133 
 Rapid reduction in tumor volume followed by acute renal failure, 
134 
hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, hyperuricemia, or hyperphosphatemia, can 
135 
occur within 12−24 hours after the first infusion.  Fatal TLS cases have 
136 
occurred after administration of Rituxan.  A high number of circulating 
137 
malignant cells ( ≥ 25,000/mm3) or high tumor burden confers a greater 
138 
risk of TLS after rituximab.  Consider prophylaxis for TLS in patients at 
139 
high risk.  Correct electrolyte abnormalities, monitor renal function and 
140 
fluid balance, and administer supportive care, including dialysis as 
141 
indicated. [See Boxed Warning.] 
142 
5.3 Severe Mucocutaneous Reactions  
143 
 Mucocutaneous reactions, some with fatal outcome, can occur in 
144 
patients treated with Rituxan.  These reactions include paraneoplastic 
145 
pemphigus, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, lichenoid dermatitis, 
146 
vesiculobullous dermatitis, and toxic epidermal necrolysis.  The onset of 
147 
these reactions has varied from 1−13 weeks following Rituxan exposure.  
148 
Discontinue Rituxan in patients who experience a severe mucocutaneous 
149 
reaction.  The safety of readministration of Rituxan to patients with severe 
150 
mucocutaneous reactions has not been determined. [See Boxed Warning, 
151 
Adverse Reactions (6.1, 6.4).] 
152 
5.4 Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) 
153 
 JC virus infection resulting in PML and death can occur in 
154 
Rituxan-treated patients with hematologic malignancies or with 
155 
autoimmune diseases.  The majority of patients with hematologic 
156 
malignancies diagnosed with PML received Rituxan in combination with 
157 
chemotherapy or as part of a hematopoietic stem cell transplant.  The 
158 
patients with autoimmune diseases had prior or concurrent 
159 
immunosuppressive therapy. Most cases of PML were diagnosed within 
160 
12 months of their last infusion of Rituxan. 
161 
 Consider the diagnosis of PML in any patient presenting with new-onset 
162 
neurologic manifestations.  Evaluation of PML includes, but is not limited 
163 
to, consultation with a neurologist, brain MRI, and lumbar puncture.  
164 
Discontinue Rituxan and consider discontinuation or reduction of any 
165 
concomitant chemotherapy or immunosuppressive therapy in patients who 
166 
develop PML. [See Boxed Warning, Adverse Reactions (6.4).] 
167 
5.5 Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) Reactivation 
168 
 Hepatitis B virus (HBV) reactivation with fulminant hepatitis, hepatic 
169 
failure, and death can occur in patients with hematologic malignancies 
170 
treated with Rituxan.  The median time to the diagnosis of hepatitis was 
171 
approximately 4 months after the initiation of Rituxan and approximately 
172 
one month after the last dose. 
173 
Page 101
 
 
 
 Screen patients at high risk of HBV infection before initiation of 
174 
Rituxan.  Closely monitor carriers of hepatitis B for clinical and laboratory 
175 
signs of active HBV infection for several months following Rituxan 
176 
therapy.  Discontinue Rituxan and any concomitant chemotherapy in 
177 
patients who develop viral hepatitis, and institute appropriate treatment 
178 
including antiviral therapy.  Insufficient data exist regarding the safety of 
179 
resuming Rituxan in patients who develop hepatitis subsequent to HBV 
180 
reactivation. [See Adverse Reactions (6.4).] 
181 
5.6 Other Viral Infections 
182 
 The following additional serious viral infections, either new, 
183 
reactivated, or exacerbated, have been identified in clinical studies or 
184 
postmarketing reports.  The majority of patients received Rituxan in 
185 
combination with chemotherapy or as part of a hematopoietic stem cell 
186 
transplant.  These viral infections included cytomegalovirus, herpes 
187 
simplex virus, parvovirus B19, varicella zoster virus, West Nile virus, and 
188 
hepatitis C.  In some cases, the viral infections occurred as late as one year 
189 
following discontinuation of Rituxan and have resulted in death. [See 
190 
Adverse Reactions (6.1, 6.4).] 
191 
5.7 Cardiovascular 
192 
 Discontinue infusions for serious or life-threatening cardiac 
193 
arrhythmias.  Perform cardiac monitoring during and after all infusions of 
194 
Rituxan for patients who develop clinically significant arrhythmias, or 
195 
who have a history of arrhythmia or angina. [See Adverse Reactions (6.4).] 
196 
5.8 Renal 
197 
 Severe, including fatal, renal toxicity can occur after Rituxan 
198 
administration in patients with hematologic malignancies.  Renal toxicity 
199 
has occurred in patients with high numbers of circulating malignant cells 
200 
( ≥ 25,000/mm3) or high tumor burden who experience tumor lysis 
201 
syndrome and in patients with NHL administered concomitant cisplatin 
202 
therapy during clinical trials.  The combination of cisplatin and Rituxan is 
203 
not an approved treatment regimen.  Use extreme caution if this non-
204 
approved combination is used in clinical trials and monitor closely for 
205 
signs of renal failure.  Consider discontinuation of Rituxan for patients 
206 
with a rising serum creatinine or oliguria. 
207 
5.9 Bowel Obstruction and Perforation 
208 
 Abdominal pain, bowel obstruction and perforation, in some cases 
209 
leading to death, can occur in patients receiving Rituxan in combination 
210 
with chemotherapy.  In postmarketing reports, the mean time to 
211 
documented gastrointestinal perforation was 6 (range 1−77) days in 
212 
patients with NHL. Perform a thorough diagnostic evaluation and institute 
213 
appropriate treatment for complaints of abdominal pain, especially early in 
214 
the course of Rituxan therapy. [See Adverse Reactions (6.4).] 
215 
Page 102
 
 
 
5.10 
Immunization 
216 
 The safety of immunization with live viral vaccines following Rituxan 
217 
therapy has not been studied and vaccination with live virus vaccines is 
218 
not recommended.  Physicians should review the vaccination status of 
219 
patients with RA being considered for Rituxan treatment and follow the 
220 
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines for adult 
221 
vaccination with non-live vaccines intended to prevent infectious disease 
222 
prior to therapy. 
223 
 For NHL patients, the benefits of primary or booster vaccinations 
224 
should be weighted against the risks of delay in initiation of Rituxan 
225 
therapy. 
226 
5.11 
Laboratory Monitoring 
227 
 Because Rituxan binds to all CD20-positive B lymphocytes (malignant 
228 
and nonmalignant), obtain complete blood counts (CBC) and platelet 
229 
counts at regular intervals during Rituxan therapy and more frequently in 
230 
patients who develop cytopenias [see Adverse Reactions (6.1)].  The 
231 
duration of cytopenias caused by Rituxan can extend months beyond the 
232 
treatment period. 
233 
5.12 
Concomitant Use with Biologic Agents and Disease Modifying 
234 
Anti-Rheumatic Drugs (DMARDS) other than Methotrexate in 
235 
RA 
236 
 Limited data are available on the safety of the use of biologic agents or 
237 
DMARDs other than methotrexate in patients exhibiting peripheral B-cell 
238 
depletion following treatment with rituximab.  Observe patients closely for 
239 
signs of infection if biologic agents and/or DMARDs are used 
240 
concomitantly. 
241 
5.13 
Use in RA Patients Who Have Not Had Prior Inadequate 
242 
Response to Tumor Necrosis Factor (TNF) Antagonists 
243 
 While efficacy of Rituxan was supported in two well-controlled trials in 
244 
patients with RA with prior inadequate responses to non-biologic 
245 
DMARDs, a favorable risk benefit relationship has not been established in 
246 
this population.  The use of Rituxan in patients with RA who have not had 
247 
prior inadequate response to one or more TNF antagonists is not 
248 
recommended [see Clinical Studies (14.5)]. 
249 
5.14 
Retreatment in Patients with RA 
250 
 Safety and efficacy of retreatment have not been established in 
251 
controlled trials.  A limited number of patients have received two to 
252 
five courses (two infusions per course) of treatment in an uncontrolled 
253 
setting.  In clinical trials in patients with RA, most of the patients who 
254 
received additional courses did so 24 weeks after the previous course and 
255 
none were retreated sooner than 16 weeks. 
256 
6 ADVERSE REACTIONS 
257 
 The following adverse reactions are discussed in greater detail in other 
258 
sections of the labeling: 
259 
Page 103
 
 
 
• Infusion reactions [see Warnings and Precautions (5.1)] 
260 
• Tumor lysis syndrome [see Warnings and Precautions (5.2)] 
261 
• Mucocutaneous reactions [see Warnings and Precautions (5.3)] 
262 
• Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy [see Warnings and 
263 
Precautions (5.4)] 
264 
• Hepatitis B reactivation with fulminant hepatitis [see Warnings and 
265 
Precautions (5.5)] 
266 
• Other viral infections [see Warnings and Precautions (5.6)] 
267 
• Cardiac arrhythmias [see Warnings and Precautions (5.7)] 
268 
• Renal toxicity [see Warnings and Precautions (5.8)] 
269 
• Bowel obstruction and perforation [see Warnings and Precautions 
270 
(5.9)] 
271 
 
272 
 The most common adverse reactions of Rituxan (incidence  ≥ 25%) 
273 
observed in patients with NHL are infusion reactions, fever, chills, 
274 
infection, asthenia, and lymphopenia. 
275 
 The most important serious adverse reactions of Rituxan are infusion 
276 
reactions, tumor lysis syndrome, mucocutaneous toxicities, hepatitis B 
277 
reactivation with fulminant hepatitis, PML, other viral infections, cardiac 
278 
arrhythmias, renal toxicity, and bowel obstruction and perforation. 
279 
6.1 Clinical Trials Experience Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma 
280 
 Because clinical trials are conducted under widely varying conditions, 
281 
adverse reaction rates observed in the clinical trials of a drug cannot be 
282 
directly compared to rates in the clinical trials of another drug and may not 
283 
reflect the rates observed in practice. 
284 
 The data described below reflect exposure to Rituxan in 1606 patients, 
285 
with exposures ranging from a single infusion up to 6−8 months.  Rituxan 
286 
was studied in both single-agent and active-controlled trials (n = 356 and 
287 
n= 1250).  These data were obtained in adults with low-grade, follicular, 
288 
or DLBCL NHL.  Most patients received Rituxan as an infusion of 375 
289 
mg/m2 per infusion, given as a single agent weekly for up to 8 doses, in 
290 
combination with chemotherapy for up to 8 doses, or following 
291 
chemotherapy for up to 16 doses.

Infusion Reactions 
293 
 In the majority of patients with NHL, infusion reactions consisting of 
294 
fever, chills/rigors, nausea, pruritus, angioedema, hypotension, headache, 
295 
bronchospasm, urticaria, rash, vomiting, myalgia, dizziness, or 
296 
hypertension occurred during the first Rituxan infusion.  Infusion reactions 
297 
typically occurred within 30 to 120 minutes of beginning the first infusion 
298 
and resolved with slowing or interruption of the Rituxan infusion and with 
299 
supportive care (diphenhydramine, acetaminophen, and intravenous 
300 
saline).  The incidence of infusion reactions was highest during the first 
301 
infusion (77%) and decreased with each subsequent infusion. [See Boxed 
302 
Warning, Warnings and Precautions (5.1).]

304 
 Serious infections (NCI CTCAE Grade 3 or 4), including sepsis, 
305 
occurred in less than 5% of patients with NHL in the single-arm studies.  
306 
The overall incidence of infections was 31% (bacterial 19%, viral 10%, 
307 
unknown 6%, and fungal 1%). [See Warnings and Precautions (5.4), (5.5), 
308 
(5.6).] 
309 
 In randomized, controlled studies where Rituxan was administered 
310 
following chemotherapy for the treatment of follicular or low-grade NHL, 
311 
the rate of infection was higher among patients who received Rituxan. In 
312 
diffuse large B-cell lymphoma patients, viral infections occurred more 
313 
frequently in those who received Rituxan.

Cytopenias and hypogammaglobulinemia 
315 
 In patients with NHL receiving rituximab monotherapy, NCI-CTC 
316 
Grade 3 and 4 cytopenias were reported in 48% of patients.  These 
317 
included lymphopenia (40%), neutropenia (6%), leukopenia (4%), anemia 
318 
(3%), and thrombocytopenia (2%).  The median duration of lymphopenia 
319 
was 14 days (range, 1−588 days) and of neutropenia was 13 days (range, 
320 
2−116 days).  A single occurrence of transient aplastic anemia (pure red 
321 
cell aplasia) and two occurrences of hemolytic anemia following Rituxan 
322 
therapy occurred during the single-arm studies. 
323 
 In studies of monotherapy, Rituxan-induced B-cell depletion occurred 
324 
in 70% to 80% of patients with NHL.  Decreased IgM and IgG serum 
325 
levels occurred in 14% of these patients.

427

6.3 Immunogenicity 
450 
 As with all therapeutic proteins, there is a potential for immunogenicity.  
451 
The observed incidence of antibody (including neutralizing antibody) 
452 
Page 110
 
 
 
positivity in an assay is highly dependent on several factors including 
453 
assay sensitivity and specificity, assay methodology, sample handling, 
454 
timing of sample collection, concomitant medications, and underlying 
455 
disease.  For these reasons, comparison of the incidence of antibodies to 
456 
Rituxan with the incidence of antibodies to other products may be 
457 
misleading. 
458 
 Using an ELISA assay, anti-human anti-chimeric antibody (HACA) 
459 
was detected in 4 of 356 (1.1%) patients with low-grade or follicular NHL 
460 
receiving single-agent Rituxan.  Three of the four patients had an objective 
461 
clinical response. 
462 
 A total of 118/1053 patients (11%) with RA tested positive for HACA 
463 
at any time after treatment with Rituxan.  Limited data are available on the 
464 
safety or efficacy of Rituxan retreatment in patients who develop HACA.  
465 
Of the 8 patients who experienced serious acute infusion reactions, 2 were 
466 
subsequently found to be HACA-positive.  Approximately 12% (14/118) 
467 
of patients who were HACA-positive had a subsequent infusion reaction 
468 
of any severity.  The clinical relevance of HACA formation in 
469 
rituximab-treated patients is unclear. 
470 
6.4 Postmarketing Experience 
471 
 The following adverse reactions have been identified during post-
472 
approval use of Rituxan in hematologic malignancies.  Because these 
473 
reactions are reported voluntarily from a population of uncertain size, it is 
474 
not always possible to reliably estimate their frequency or establish a 
475 
causal relationship to drug exposure.   
Decisions to include these 
476 
reactions in labeling are typically based on one or more of the following 
477 
factors:  (1) seriousness of the reaction, (2) frequency of reporting, or (3) 
478 
strength of causal connection to Rituxan. 
479 
• Hematologic:  prolonged pancytopenia, marrow hypoplasia, and late-
480 
onset neutropenia, hyperviscosity syndrome in Waldenstrom’s 
481 
macroglobulinemia. 
482 
• Cardiac:  fatal cardiac failure. 
483 
• Immune/Autoimmune Events:  uveitis, optic neuritis, systemic 
484 
vasculitis, pleuritis, lupus-like syndrome, serum sickness, polyarticular 
485 
arthritis, and vasculitis with rash. 
486 
• Infection:  viral infections, including progressive multifocal 
487 
leukoencephalopathy (PML), increase in fatal infections in 
488 
HIV-associated lymphoma, and a reported increased incidence of Grade 
489 
3 and 4 infections in patients with previously treated lymphoma without 
490 
known HIV infection. 
491 
• Neoplasia:  disease progression of Kaposi’s sarcoma. 
492 
• Skin:  severe mucocutaneous reactions. 
493 
• Gastrointestinal:  bowel obstruction and perforation. 
494 
• Pulmonary:  fatal bronchiolitis obliterans and pneumonitis (including 
495 
interstitial pneumonitis).

7 DRUG INTERACTIONS 
497 
 Formal drug interaction studies have not been performed with Rituxan.  
498 
In clinical trials of patients with RA, concomitant administration of 
499 
methotrexate or cyclophosphamide did not alter the pharmacokinetics of 
500 
rituximab. 
501 
8 USE IN SPECIFIC POPULATIONS 
502 
8.1 Pregnancy 
503 
 Category C:  There are no adequate and well-controlled studies of 
504 
rituximab in pregnant women.  Postmarketing data indicate that B-cell 
505 
lymphocytopenia generally lasting less than six months can occur in 
506 
infants exposed to rituximab in-utero.  Rituximab was detected postnatally 
507 
in the serum of infants exposed in-utero.   
508 
 Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma and moderate-severe rheumatoid arthritis 
509 
are serious conditions that require treatment.  Rituximab should be used 
510 
during pregnancy only if the potential benefit to the mother justifies the 
511 
potential risk to the fetus. 
512 
 Reproduction studies in cynomolgus monkeys at maternal exposures 
513 
similar to human therapeutic exposures showed no evidence of teratogenic 
514 
effects.  However, B-cell lymphoid tissue was reduced in the offspring of 
515 
treated dams.  The B-cell counts returned to normal levels, and 
516 
immunologic function was restored within 6 months of birth. 
517 
  
518 
8.3 Nursing Mothers 
519 
 It is not known whether Rituxan is secreted into human milk.  However, 
520 
Rituxan is secreted in the milk of lactating cynomolgus monkeys, and IgG 
521 
is excreted in human milk.  Published data suggest that antibodies in 
522 
breast milk do not enter the neonatal and infant circulations in substantial 
523 
amounts.  The unknown risks to the infant from oral ingestion of Rituxan 
524 
should be weighed against the known benefits of breastfeeding. 
525 
8.4 Pediatric Use 
526 
 The safety and effectiveness of Rituxan in pediatric patients have not 
527 
been established. 
528 
8.5 Geriatric Use 
529 
Diffuse Large B-Cell NHL 
530 
 Among patients with DLBCL evaluated in three randomized, 
531 
active-controlled trials, 927 patients received Rituxan in combination with 
532 
chemotherapy.  Of these, 396 (43%) were age 65 or greater and 123 (13%) 
533 
were age 75 or greater.  No overall differences in effectiveness were 
534 
observed between these patients and younger patients.  Cardiac adverse 
535 
reactions, mostly supraventricular arrhythmias, occurred more frequently 
536 
among elderly patients.  Serious pulmonary adverse reactions were also 
537 
more common among the elderly, including pneumonia and pneumonitis. 
538 
Page 112
 
 
 
Low-Grade or Follicular Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma 
539 
 Clinical studies of Rituxan in low-grade or follicular, CD20-positive, 
540 
B-cell NHL did not include sufficient numbers of patients aged 65 and 
541 
over to determine whether they respond differently from younger subjects. 
542 
Rheumatoid Arthritis 
543 
 Among the 517 patients in the Phase 3 RA study, 16% were 
544 
65−75 years old and 2% were 75 years old and older.  Response rates and

(age < 65 years) patients.

11 DESCRIPTION 
552 
 Rituxan (rituximab) is a genetically engineered chimeric 
553 
murine/human monoclonal IgG1 kappa antibody directed against the CD20 
554 
antigen. Rituximab has an approximate molecular weight of 145 kD.  
555 
Rituximab has a binding affinity for the CD20 antigen of approximately 
556 
8.0 nM. 
557 
 Rituximab is produced by mammalian cell (Chinese Hamster Ovary) 
558 
suspension culture in a nutrient medium containing the antibiotic 
559 
gentamicin.  Gentamicin is not detectable in the final product.  Rituxan is 
560 
a sterile, clear, colorless, preservative-free liquid concentrate for 
561 
intravenous administration.  Rituxan is supplied at a concentration of 
562 
10 mg/mL in either 100 mg (10 mL) or 500 mg (50 mL) single-use vials.  
563 
The product is formulated in 9 mg/mL sodium chloride, 7.35 mg/mL 
564 
sodium citrate dihydrate, 0.7 mg/mL polysorbate 80, and Water for 
565 
Injection.  The pH is 6.5. 
566 
12 CLINICAL PHARMACOLOGY 
567 
12.1 
Mechanism of Action 
568 
 Rituximab binds specifically to the antigen CD20 (human 
569 
B-lymphocyte-restricted differentiation antigen, Bp35), a hydrophobic 
570 
transmembrane protein with a molecular weight of approximately 35 kD 
571 
located on pre-B and mature B lymphocytes.  The antigen is expressed 
572 
on > 90% of B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas (NHL), but the antigen is 
573 
not found on hematopoietic stem cells, pro-B-cells, normal plasma cells or 
574 
other normal tissues.  CD20 regulates an early step(s) in the activation 
575 
process for cell cycle initiation and differentiation, and possibly functions 
576 
as a calcium ion channel.  CD20 is not shed from the cell surface and does 
577 
not internalize upon antibody binding.  Free CD20 antigen is not found in 
578 
the circulation. 
579 
 B cells are believed to play a role in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid 
580 
arthritis (RA) and associated chronic synovitis.  In this setting, B cells may 
581 
be acting at multiple sites in the autoimmune/inflammatory process, 
582 
Page 113
 
 
 
including through production of rheumatoid factor (RF) and other 
583 
autoantibodies, antigen presentation, T-cell activation, and/or pro-
584 
inflammatory cytokine production. 
585 
 Mechanism of Action:  The Fab domain of rituximab binds to the CD20 
586 
antigen on B lymphocytes, and the Fc domain recruits immune effector 
587 
functions to mediate B-cell lysis in vitro.  Possible mechanisms of cell 
588 
lysis include complement-dependent cytotoxicity (CDC) and 
589 
antibody-dependent cell mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC).  The antibody has 
590 
been shown to induce apoptosis in the DHL-4 human B-cell lymphoma 
591 
line. 
592 
 Normal Tissue Cross-reactivity:  Rituximab binding was observed on 
593 
lymphoid cells in the thymus, the white pulp of the spleen, and a majority 
594 
of B lymphocytes in peripheral blood and lymph nodes.  Little or no 
595 
binding was observed in the non-lymphoid tissues examined. 
596 
12.2 
Pharmacodynamics 
597 
 Administration of Rituxan resulted in a rapid and sustained depletion of 
598 
circulating and tissue-based B cells.  Among 166 patients in Study 1, 
599 
circulating CD19-positive B cells were depleted within the first three 
600 
weeks with sustained depletion for up to 6 to 9 months post-treatment in 
601 
83% of patients.  B-cell recovery began at approximately 6 months and 
602 
median B-cell levels returned to normal by 12 months following 
603 
completion of treatment. 
604 
 There were sustained and statistically significant reductions in both IgM 
605 
and IgG serum levels observed from 5 through 11 months following 
606 
rituximab administration; 14% of patients had IgM and/or IgG serum 
607 
levels below the normal range. 
608 
 In RA patients, treatment with Rituxan induced depletion of peripheral 
609 
B lymphocytes, with all patients demonstrating near complete depletion 
610 
within 2 weeks after receiving the first dose of Rituxan.  The majority of 
611 
patients showed peripheral B-cell depletion for at least 6 months, followed 
612 
by subsequent gradual recovery after that timepoint.  A small proportion 
613 
of patients (4%) had prolonged peripheral B-cell depletion lasting more 
614 
than 3 years after a single course of treatment. 
615 
 In RA studies, total serum immunoglobulin levels, IgM, IgG, and IgA 
616 
were reduced at 6 months with the greatest change observed in IgM.  
617 
However, mean immunoglobulin levels remained within normal levels 
618 
over the 24-week period.  Small proportions of patients experienced 
619 
decreases in IgM (7%), IgG (2%), and IgA (1%) levels below the lower 
620 
limit of normal.  The clinical consequences of decreases in 
621 
immunoglobulin levels in RA patients treated with Rituxan are unclear. 
622 
 Treatment with rituximab in patients with RA was associated with 
623 
reduction of certain biologic markers of inflammation such as 
624 
interleukin-6 (IL-6), C-reactive protein (CRP), serum amyloid protein 
625 
(SAA), S100 A8/S100 A9 heterodimer complex (S100 A8/9), 
626 
anti-citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP), and RF. 
627 
Page 114
 
 
 
12.3 
Pharmacokinetics 
628 
 Pharmacokinetics were characterized in 203 NHL patients receiving 
629 
375 mg/m2 rituximab weekly by IV infusion for 4 doses.  The mean Cmax 
630 
increased with each successive infusion and was 486 mcg/mL (range, 
631 
78−997 mcg/mL) following the fourth infusion. Peak and trough serum 
632 
levels of rituximab were inversely correlated with pretreatment circulating 
633 
CD19-positive B cells and tumor burden.  Rituximab was detectable in the 
634 
serum of patients 3 to 6 months after completion of treatment. 
635 
 The pharmacokinetic profile of rituximab when administered as 
636 
6 infusions of 375 mg/m2 in combination with 6 cycles of CHOP 
637 
chemotherapy was similar to that seen with rituximab alone. 
638 
 Based on a population pharmacokinetic analysis of data from 298 NHL 
639 
patients who received rituximab once weekly or once every three weeks, 
640 
the estimated median terminal elimination half-life was 22 days (range, 
641 
6.1 to 52 days).  Patients with higher CD19-positive cell counts or larger 
642 
measurable tumor lesions at pretreatment had a higher clearance.  
643 
However, dose adjustment for pretreatment CD19 count or size of tumor 
644 
lesion is not necessary.  Age and gender had no effect on the 
645 
pharmacokinetics of rituximab. 
646 
 Following administration of 2 doses of rituximab in patients with 
647 
rheumatoid arthritis, the mean Cmax values were 183 mcg/mL (CV = 24%) 
648 
for the 2 × 500 mg dose and 370 mcg/mL (CV = 25%) for the 
649 
2 × 1000 mg dose, respectively.  Following 2 × 1000 mg rituximab dose, 
650 
mean volume of distribution at steady state was 4.3L (CV = 28%).  Mean 
651 
systemic serum clearance of rituximab was 0.01L/h (CV = 38%), and 
652 
mean terminal elimination half-life after the second dose was 19 days 
653 
(CV = 32%). 
654 
 Female patients with RA (n = 86) had a 37% lower clearance of 
655 
rituximab than male patients with RA (n = 25).  The gender difference in 
656 
rituximab clearance does not necessitate any dose adjustment because 
657 
safety and efficacy of rituximab do not appear to be influenced by gender. 
658 
 The pharmacokinetics of rituximab have not been studied in children 
659 
and adolescents.  No formal studies were conducted to examine the effects 
660 
of either renal or hepatic impairment on the pharmacokinetics of 
661 
rituximab. 
662 
13 NONCLINICAL TOXICOLOGY 
663 
13.1 
Carcinogenesis, Mutagenesis, Impairment of Fertility 
664 
 No long-term animal studies have been performed to establish the 
665 
carcinogenic or mutagenic potential of Rituxan or to determine potential 
666 
effects on fertility in males or females. 
667 
13.2 
Animal Toxicology and/or Pharmacology 
668 
Reproductive Toxicology Studies 
669 
 An embryo-fetal developmental toxicity study was performed on 
670 
pregnant cynomolgus monkeys.  Pregnant animals received rituximab via 
671 
Page 115
 
 
 
the intravenous route during early gestation (organogenesis period; post-
672 
coitum days 20 through 50).  Rituximab was administered as loading 
673 
doses on post-coitum (PC) days 20, 21 and 22, at 15, 37.5 or 
674 
75 mg/kg/day, and then weekly on PC Days 29, 36, 43 and 50, at 20, 50 or 
675 
100 mg/kg/week.  The 100 mg/kg/week dose resulted in 80% of the 
676 
exposure (based on AUC) of those achieved following a dose of 2 grams 
677 
in humans. Rituximab crosses the monkey placenta.  Exposed offspring 
678 
did not exhibit any teratogenic effects but did have decreased lymphoid 
679 
tissue B cells. 
680 
 A subsequent pre- and postnatal reproductive toxicity study in 
681 
cynomolgus monkeys was completed to assess developmental effects 
682 
including the recovery of B cells and immune function in infants exposed 
683 
to rituximab in utero.  Animals were treated with a loading dose of 0, 15, 
684 
or 75 mg/kg every day for 3 days, followed by weekly dosing with 0, 20, 
685 
or 100 mg/kg dose. Subsets of pregnant females were treated from PC Day 
686 
20 through postpartum Day 78, PC Day 76 through PC Day 134, and from 
687 
PC day 132 through delivery and postpartum Day 28. Regardless of the 
688 
timing of treatment, decreased B cells and immunosuppression were noted 
689 
in the offspring of rituximab-treated pregnant animals.  The B-cell counts 
690 
returned to normal levels, and immunologic function was restored within 
691 
6 months postpartum. 
692

CD20-Positive, B-Cell NHL

696 
NHL were demonstrated in 3 single-arm studies enrolling 296 patients.

Study 1

699

700

study.

 Results are summarized in Table 3.  The median time to onset of

B-symptoms) resolved in 64% (25/39) of those patients with such 
707 
symptoms at study entry.

 In a multicenter, single-arm study, 37 patients with relapsed or

8 doses.  Results are summarized in Table 3.

Study 3

 In a multicenter, single-arm study, 60 patients received 375 mg/m2 of

Rituxan weekly for 4 doses.  All patients had relapsed or refractory,

Study 5 
748 
 A total of 322 patients with previously untreated low-grade, B-cell NHL 
749 
who did not progress after 6 or 8 cycles of CVP chemotherapy were 
750

751

757

 There was a reduction in the risk of progression, relapse, or death 
759

760 
to Rituxan as compared to those who received no additional treatment.

14.4 
Diffuse Large B-Cell NHL (DLBCL) 
762 
 The safety and effectiveness of Rituxan were evaluated in three 
763 
randomized, active-controlled, open-label, multicenter studies with a 
764 
collective enrollment of 1854 patients.  Patients with previously untreated 
765 
diffuse large B-cell NHL received Rituxan in combination with 
766 
cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone (CHOP) or 
767 
other anthracycline-based chemotherapy regimens. 
768 
Study 6 
769 
 A total of 632 patients age  ≥ 60 years with DLBCL (including primary 
770 
mediastinal B-cell lymphoma) were randomized in a 1:1 ratio to treatment 
771 
with CHOP or R-CHOP.  Patients received 6 or 8 cycles of CHOP, each 
772 
cycle lasting 21 days.  All patients in the R-CHOP arm received 4 doses of 
773 
Rituxan 375 mg/m2 on Days -7 and -3 (prior to Cycle 1) and 48−72 hours 
774 
prior to Cycles 3 and 5.  Patients who received 8 cycles of CHOP also 
775 
received Rituxan prior to cycle 7.  The main outcome measure of the study 
776 
was progression-free survival, defined as the time from randomization to 
777 
the first of progression, relapse, or death.  Responding patients underwent 
778 
a second randomization to receive Rituxan or no further therapy. 
779 
 Among all enrolled patients, 62% had centrally confirmed DLBCL 
780 
histology, 73% had Stage III−IV disease, 56% had IPI scores  ≥ 2, 86% 
781 
Page 118
 
 
 
had ECOG performance status of  < 2, 57% had elevated LDH levels, and 
782 
30% had two or more extranodal disease sites involved.  Efficacy results 
783 
are presented in Table 5.  These results reflect a statistical approach which 
784 
allows for an evaluation of Rituxan administered in the induction setting 
785 
that excludes any potential impact of Rituxan given after the second 
786 
randomization. 
787 
 Analysis of results after the second randomization in Study 6 
788 
demonstrates that for patients randomized to R-CHOP, additional Rituxan 
789 
exposure beyond induction was not associated with further improvements 
790 
in progression-free survival or overall survival. 
791

793

794

795

796

797 
randomization to relapse, progression, change in therapy, or death from 
798 
any cause.  Among all enrolled patients, 80% had Stage III or IV disease, 
799 
60% of patients had an age-adjusted IPI  ≥ 2, 80% had ECOG 
800 
performance status scores  < 2, 66% had elevated LDH levels, and 52% 
801 
had extranodal involvement in at least two sites.  Efficacy results are 
802 
presented in Table 5.

16 HOW SUPPLIED/STORAGE AND HANDLING 
860 
 Rituxan vials [100 mg (NDC 50242-051-21) and 500 mg 
861 
(NDC 50242-053-06)] are stable at 2°C−8°C (36°F−46°F).  Do not use 
862 
beyond expiration date stamped on carton.  Rituxan vials should be 
863 
protected from direct sunlight.  Do not freeze or shake. 
864 
 Rituxan solutions for infusion may be stored at 2°C−8°C (36°F−46°F) 
865 
for 24 hours.  Rituxan solutions for infusion have been shown to be stable 
866 
for an additional 24 hours at room temperature.  However, since Rituxan 
867 
solutions do not contain a preservative, diluted solutions should be stored 
868 
refrigerated (2°C−8°C).  No incompatibilities between Rituxan and 
869 
polyvinylchloride or polyethylene bags have been observed.

should be exercised in administering Rituxan to patients with active

 Rituxan is detectable in serum for up to six months following

completion of therapy.  Individuals of childbearing potential should use

effective contraception during treatment and for 12 months after Rituxan

therapy.

17.2 
Medication Guide 
884 
MEDICATION GUIDE 
885 
RITUXAN® (ri-tuk´-san) 
886 
(rituximab) 
887 
Read the Medication Guide given to you before you start Rituxan and 
888 
before each Rituxan infusion.  The information may have changed.  This 
889 
Medication Guide does not take the place of talking to your doctor about 
890 
your medical condition or your treatment.  Talk with your doctor if you 
891 
have any questions about your treatment with Rituxan. 
892 
What is the most important information I should know about 
893 
Rituxan? 
894 
Rituxan can cause serious side effects including: 
895 
• Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) 
896 
• 
PML is a rare brain infection.  PML usually causes death or severe 
897 
disability. 
898 
• 
Call your doctor right away if you notice any new or worsening 
899 
medical problems, such as a new or sudden change in thinking, 
900 
walking, strength, vision, or other problems that have lasted over 
901 
several days. 
902 
• 
PML usually happens in patients with weakened immune systems. 
903 
• 
PML can occur during treatment with Rituxan or after treatment 
904 
has finished. 
905 
• 
There is no known treatment, prevention, or cure for PML. 
906 
•   
Infusion reactions.  Tell your doctor or get medical treatment right 
907 
away if you get hives, swelling, dizziness, blurred vision, drowsiness, 
908 
headache, cough, wheezing, or have trouble breathing while receiving 
909 
or after receiving Rituxan. 
910 
•   
Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS).  TLS is caused by the fast 
911 
breakdown of certain types of cancer cells.  TLS can cause kidney 
912 
failure and the need for dialysis treatment.  Patients receiving Rituxan 
913 
for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (NHL) may get TLS.  Your doctor will 
914 
check you for TLS. 
915 
•   
Severe skin reactions.  Tell your doctor or get medical treatment 
916 
right away if you get any of these symptoms:  painful sores on your 
917 
skin or in your mouth, ulcers, blisters, or peeling skin while receiving 
918 
or after receiving Rituxan. 
919 
See “What are possible side effects with Rituxan?” for other serious 
920 
side effects. 
921 
What is Rituxan? 
922 
Rituxan is a prescription medicine used in adults: 
923 
•   
alone or with other anti-cancer medicines to treat certain types of 
924 
NHL. 
925 
•   
with another medicine called methotrexate to reduce the signs and 
926 
symptoms of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) after at least one other 
927 
medicine called a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor has been used 
928 
and did not work well. 
929 
Page 124
 
 
 
Rituxan has not been studied in children. 
930 
What should I tell my doctor before treatment with Rituxan? 
931 
Tell your doctor about all of your medical conditions, including if you: 
932 
•   
had a severe infusion reaction to Rituxan in the past. 
933 
•   
have an infection or have an infection that will not go away or that 
934 
keeps coming back. 
935 
•   
have or had hepatitis (liver) infection.  See “What are the possible 
936 
side effects of Rituxan?” If so, your doctor should check you closely 
937 
for signs of hepatitis infection during treatment with Rituxan and for 
938 
several months after treatment ends. 
939 
•   
are scheduled to receive any vaccinations.  You should not receive 
940 
live vaccines after you receive Rituxan. 
941 
•   
have heart or lung problems. 
942 
•   
are pregnant or planning to become pregnant.  It is not known if 
943 
Rituxan can harm your unborn baby. 
944 
•   
are breastfeeding.  It is not known if Rituxan passes into human breast 
945 
milk.  You should not breastfeed while being treated with Rituxan and 
946 
after finishing treatment, until blood tests show that there is no 
947 
Rituxan in your blood. 
948 
Tell your doctor about all the medicines you take, including prescription 
949 
and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, or herbal supplements.  If you 
950 
have RA, especially tell your doctor if you take or have taken another 
951 
medicine called a TNF inhibitor or a DMARD (disease modifying 
952 
anti-rheumatic drug). 
953 
How do I receive Rituxan? 
954 
•   
Rituxan is given through a needle placed in a vein (IV or intravenous 
955 
infusion), in your arm.  Talk to your doctor about how you will 
956 
receive Rituxan. 
957 
•   
Your doctor may prescribe medicines before each infusion of Rituxan 
958 
to reduce side effects of infusions (such as fever and chills). 
959 
•   
Your doctor should do regular blood tests to check for side effects to 
960 
Rituxan. 
961 
Before each Rituxan treatment, your doctor or nurse will ask you 
962 
questions about your general health to make sure that Rituxan is still right 
963 
for you.  Tell your doctor or nurse about any new symptoms, and 
964 
symptoms that get worse over a few days or that will not go away. 
965 
Page 125
 
 
 
What are the possible side effects of Rituxan? 
966 
The “What is the most important information I should know about 
967 
Rituxan?” section lists certain serious and life-threatening side effects 
968 
with Rituxan.  Rituxan can cause other serious and life-threatening side 
969 
effects including: 
970 
•   
Hepatitis B virus reactivation.  Tell your doctor if you had 
971 
hepatitis B virus or are a carrier of hepatitis B virus.  Receiving 
972 
Rituxan could cause the hepatitis B virus to become an active 
973 
infection again.  This may cause serious liver problems and death.  
974 
People with active liver disease due to hepatitis B should stop 
975 
receiving Rituxan. 
976 
•   
Heart problems.  Tell your doctor about any heart problems you 
977 
have including chest pain (angina) and irregular heart beats.  Rituxan 
978 
can cause chest pain and irregular heart beats which may require 
979 
treatment. 
980 
•   
Infections.  Rituxan can increase your chances for getting infections.  
981 
Call your doctor right away if you have a cough that will not go away, 
982 
fever, chills, congestion, or any flu-like symptoms while receiving 
983 
Rituxan.  These symptoms may be signs of a serious infection. 
984 
•   
Stomach and bowel problems.  Serious stomach and bowel 
985 
problems have been seen when Rituxan has been used with 
986 
anti-cancer medicines in some patients with non-Hodgkin’s 
987 
lymphoma.  Call your doctor right away if you have any stomach area 
988 
pain during treatment with Rituxan. 
989 
Common side effects during Rituxan infusions include: 
990 
•   fever 
• headache 
991 
•   chills and shakes 
• nausea 
992 
•   itching 
• hives 
993 
• 
cough 
• sneezing 
994 
• 
throat irritation or tightness 
995 
 
996 
Other side effects with Rituxan include: 
997 
•   aching joints 
998 
•   upper respiratory tract infection 
999 
•   decreased blood cell counts 
1000 
•   lung problems 
1001 
 
1002 
Tell your doctor about any side effect that bothers you or that does not go 
1003 
away.  These are not all of the possible side effects with Rituxan.  Ask 
1004 
your doctor for more information. 
1005
